content.question: The diagrams above represent two samples of <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gas in containers of equal volume at <math alttext="280 kelvins" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>280</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following correctly compares the two samples in terms of their deviation from ideal gas behavior and explains why?

choices.label: The gas in sample 1 would deviate more from ideal behavior because the average distance an <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></math> atom travels before colliding with another <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is greater.

The gas in sample 2 would deviate more from ideal behavior because the <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms are closer together, leading to an increase in intermolecular attractions.

The gas in sample 2 would deviate more from ideal behavior because the average speed of the <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms is less, leading to an increase in intermolecular attractions.
The gases in both sample 1 and sample 2 would show the same deviation from ideal behavior.

content.answer: The gas in sample 2 would deviate more from ideal behavior because the <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms are closer together, leading to an increase in intermolecular attractions.
